The Hows of UsOne of the best KathNiel films for me. Itâ€™s one of my feel-good Pinoy movies. Iâ€™ve seen it three times, and I just had some realizations about relationships.After rewatching it, I found myself reflecting again on how love can be so complicated. What makes it more meaningful is not just the love itselfâ€”but the presence of understanding, respect, and the choice to keep showing up for each other. Itâ€™s not always about grand gestures. Sometimes, itâ€™s the quiet assurance, the willingness to stay, and the help you give one another when things get tough that matter the most.Love is not always filled with happy or funny daysâ€”there will be real struggles to face. But having a partner who truly gets you, who wonâ€™t make you feel like a burden even in your lowest momentsâ€”thatâ€™s something else. Itâ€™s a different kind of feeling when youâ€™re sharing your life with someone who sees your mess and still chooses to stay. That kind of love feels safe. It feels like home.Living together isnâ€™t easy. But what makes it bearableâ€”even beautifulâ€”is when both people make the choice to stay, to fight for the love they share. It should never be one-sided. A relationship thrives when both partners are making an effort. Communication, respect, loyalty, and understandingâ€”these are the pillars that hold love together.Sharing a home means sharing lives, dreams, flaws, and even pain. Itâ€™s not just about romance; itâ€™s about commitment. Itâ€™s choosing each other every day, even in the midst of exhaustion, misunderstandings, and storms. There will be moments of doubt, words spoken in anger, and days when love feels more like a burden than a comfortâ€”but staying, especially during the storm, is what love truly asks of us.Before entering a lifelong commitment, ask yourself:Are you truly ready to live with someone through the calm and the chaos, the ease and the effort?Are you ready to love, not just in the good timesâ€”but especially in the hardest ones?Are you ready to choose them again and again, even when itâ€™s no longer easy?The Hows of Us doesnâ€™t just show us what love looks likeâ€”it shows us what it takes. And if youâ€™re with the right person, every hardship turns into something beautiful.

Ang peste kahit gaano kagwapo, peste pa rin yan.Star Cinema really thought they could gaslight us by the sudden shift from heavy drama to romcom-ish. How could I feel kilig when the â€œbatugan na palamunin na makasarili na tine-take advantage ang iniwan na kalahating titulo ng bahay na hindi naman talaga sa kanya in the first placeâ€ male lead starts to win back the strong independent female lead who had to give up her dreams once just to clean after his mess. Because I canâ€™t, all I feel is rage and stupidity for Georgeâ€™s side. After going through all of that how can she go back.Napakaunnecessary at forced ng Amsterdam. But in the first place, there should be no war to win, only a journey that you go through. Mas madali kasing umayaw â€™pag masakit na, bumitaw â€™pag pagod na. Pero ang totoo, ang kailangan niyo lang patience. If you only held on, matututuhan niyo pa rin ang mga â€™yan. Mag-ggrow pa rin kayo together. O, look at my plants. Sometimes, they need space to grow at some, they grow better together.INDEED!!!!!

Pag binalik ni Primo yung time ng nmat ni George, doon ako papayag na patawarin siya. nmat yun nmat!!! All the man in George's life failed her, my heart aches for her ğŸ˜­Okay marupok si George. But do they really love each other o nag ho hold on na lang sila sa memories and unsolved shits nila in the past? Also, ang panget nung binigyan ng "excuse" yung pagiging gago ni Primo. Alam niya na nasasaktan niya sa George pero wala siyang ginawa. Tsaka nakakainis lang na kailangan niya magkaroon ng "traumatic experience" after niya iwan si George na para bang kailangan siya patawarin kasi may masama rin naman siyang pinagdaanan. Ulol! Pwedeng naransan niya yun pero nasaktan niya pa rin si George. Grabeng panggago yan di ko matanggap yung redemption arc niya. Taena rin ni Yohan HAHAHAHAH sarap batukan eh. Maganda lang talaga yung script, cinematography, tsaka acting ni Kathreen. Sobrang promising din nung unang parts. Di ko lang talaga bet yung ending ğŸ¤§Inubos nila ang Amsterdam jokes nila dito. Mikko, I was rooting for you ğŸ˜¢

tinanong kita 'ano paborito mong lokal na pelikula' sabi mo 'the hows of us' sabi ko 'ano yun'. pumamewang ka at umiling sa dismaya na para bang gusto mong tanggalin ang pagkapilipino ko. pinaupo mo ako at pinanood natin to. pagpupugay sayo at sa sikmura mong matibay.sabi mo, may iconic na eksena dito -- yung jeep scene na nagkakandarapa si primo sa hulas at lasing, at pilit siyang inaakay ni george kahit pa talikuran niya na yung exam na buong buhay niyang pinaghandaan. lumingon ka ng tingin kasi sabi mo nakalulungkot.pinanood ko ulit to ngayon kasi nakikipag kara-krus ako sa tulog at puyat. sabi mo, may isa pang iconic na eksena dito -- yung monologue ni george na 'pagod na pagod na pagod na ako'. pabiro mong sinabayan bigkasin ni kathryn linya por linya. doon ang pangalawang beses na pumihit ang sikmura ko.napagusapan natin, paano kung ako ang nasa lagay ni primo? babalikan mo ba ako? hindi pa tapos ang tanong pero nasagot mo na ng mariin na oo. sabi mo, hindi ko alam kung anong pambababoy sa pagkatao ang kaya mong gawin sa sarili mo para lang sa akin. hindi ako nakatulog noong gabing iyon dahil lumalampas sa pisngi ko ang ngiti. dumating tayo sa puntong kailangan nating maghiwalay, at hindi rin ako nakatulog noong gabing iyonpinanood ko ulit to ngayon kasi nakikipag kara-krus ako sa mga bukas kong sugat na hindi kumikirot hanggaâ€™t hindi tinitingnan. sa totoo lang, gusto ko lang makaramdam ulit.sabi mo tuwing Linggo, malulungkot ka dahil sa atin nakalaan ang araw na iyon at doon mo ako maaalala. tuwing Linggo nagdarasal ako na daanan ka ng matinding kalungkutan at magpapamisa ako sa Quiapo kapag nangyari iyon. tuwing Lunes, hinihintay ko mag Linggo. pero hindi dapat ganoon dahil napupuno ang mga araw ko ng mga ikaw. sayo na tong pelikula mo tangina ka. okei naman 4/5 hehe

The Howâ€™s of Us captures the kind of relationship that feels real â€” messy, painful, and full of the quiet moments that make love worth holding onto. Kathryn Bernardo and Daniel Padilla deliver their best performances yet; their chemistry is raw and mature, showing what it really means to love someone through the highs and lows.Itâ€™s not just a romance â€” itâ€™s a reflection on growing up, on chasing dreams without losing yourself (or the person you love along the way). The emotions are so grounded that you canâ€™t help but see a bit of yourself in Primo and George.Some scenes hurt to watch, but in the best way possible. The Howâ€™s of Us reminds us that sometimes love isnâ€™t about staying the same â€” itâ€™s about growing together, even when it hurts.

Honestly, I don't understand why people are doing those things when they are in love. This is the reason I'm scared to fall kasi I can't do this kind of commitment. I mean loving someone brings you joy, yes, but you can't have only one side of the coin. Love can also make you suffer. Like it did to these two. For years they suffered. Well I guess atleast they make up in the end. But still, I don't think I can do what Jo did, sticking to the person they love even though her dreams are slowly getting out of reach. Maybe I'm just scared but by the gods I would rather be alone than experience such gut wrenching pain. Wala naman po nanakit sakin. I just saw how love can build things but also destroy a lot of things. No hate to those people who love love. Maybe it's just not my cup of tea. This movie just showed me the real truth about love. That it's not always nice and loving. And that makes me more scared to try.

For the couples drowning in love and survival.Primo (Daniel Padilla) and George (Kathryn Bernardo) are the embodiment of â€œmahal pero pagod na.â€ Love alone isnâ€™t enough when dreams and pride collide. The line that cut deepest: â€œSawang-sawa na kong magmahal sa â€™yo.â€ Itâ€™s cruel, yet so honest. This movie is about the wear and tear of long-term loveâ€”the kind that tests your patience and your will to stay.Pero the most painful line for me was George saying:â€œI needed you to fight for us that night, because I was tired fighting alone.â€Ang bigat. Kasi love is supposed to be sharedâ€”hindi pwedeng isa lang ang lumalaban. When she said that, it showed how empty and one-sided their relationship had become.For me, George shouldnâ€™t have gone back to Primo. The braver, healthier ending wouldâ€™ve been choosing herself. Love canâ€™t survive kung ikaw lang ang may hawak ng lubid habang yung isa paulit-ulit na bibitaw. Walking away doesnâ€™t erase the love, but it proves na self-respect and peace are worth more than a history that keeps breaking you. George deserved someone who would fight with her, not leave her fighting alone.

Due to I can't find again the movie I was supposed to watch again today because I want to watch movies that was never heard of or already been buried too deep, I decided to use my sister payment to that hideous app (Netflix). Because in years of subscribing to that app, the ones I've always wanted to watch are not in this app and no, I'm not gonna risk my time and waste it by watching their own horrible production films. Crazy that they managed to change their price when they couldn't even give me a qualityâ€¦ you're really just enjoying this app if you're still a koreaboo (at this time), if you're also a Filipino media enjoyer or an Adam Sandler movie enjoyer and thankfully, I'm not one of either of the three. So yeah that app is just being logged in our TV but no one is actually using it unless we have friends coming over. Totally a waste of money I think but my mother is enjoying it I guessâ€¦I literally just said what the hell. If I can't always find the movie I wanted to watch then I'm just wasting the consecutive suspensions of classes so yeah fawk it, I will just whatever's on the table. Well, it's not exactly in the table because I still searched in this app what hideous film I would waste my time and something ticks in me that I should watch a Kathniel movie because why not? And then I remembered that this is one of their films that I still haven't watched but knowing how impactful it is to this country, maybe this is the time. You know, I have always been not a fan of Kathniel. I mean, I don't hate them so much like it's not about them. I just don't invest in Filipino media so much because it hurts to admit but we are really bad at everything in here from the movies, televisions, music and everything so that's why I stopped investing in that side. But #trust that whenever there's an issue lying around of course, I'll be there. I'm sorry I'm just a normal Filipino who loves gossip and nosing my butt in other's lives. I remembered back when I was Grade 12, we had a roleplay activity that we had to do in front of us and we had some movie references that we could copy and this movie is one of them. First is, the teacher showed us the scene of Kathrynâ€™s crying in the rain scene and lol I literally take a picture of that and posted in my story and said that this woman really cannot act and all my classmates saw it and laugh about it so that's why one of the best known of me is being a hater of Kathryn Bernardo. And hey! I'm sorry if I was called that . I never wanted it and I never intended to. I was just being honest and I told you that I still haven't watched this movie so watching that scene out of context really brought the wrong and early judgment of me. But this is why I'm changed now that I watched this film. I don't know if I can do it since I still haven't watched all of her films but based on the films that I watched, this really might be her best performance yet. But I wouldn't say the bestâ€¦ I mean she definitely improved maybe because her roles have always been the same for years and this role back then might be the most mature one yet and I really see that. Her character here is one of the best ones she played and one of the best written yet considering this was written by the same director who always gives the same quality of characters for me. There's an attempt here that I really appreciate but I still hope that it could've been more just like the rest of all people. I need her to be bolder, stronger and better. But it's enough I guess if this is actually the story they wanted to portray since the start.I know one thing that we can agree on liking this. The YEARNING. It might be the best love approach that can be shown in the media. And it's rare for me to watch a Filipino movie that the yearning was done right. This is the highlight of the film for me. You can really feel the coupleâ€™s chemistry in this movie and I understand and see that considering this is one of this couple's peak years. I was smiling, giggling like a girl and entertained. But it's also annoying to watch now. I think this is really one of the films that can be watched back then but cannot be now. This is their best role yet if we're gonna base it on the chemistry like they're literally just being a couple in here but with a plot. And it's making me mad that they can't be like that off camera now because this man played his role a little too well. Fawk this guy to death like I wish he never finds a stardom again after what he did to their relationship. Everybody is worshiping your relationship like it was a major holiday whenever you're doing something. But you are also the one who ruined it. Men really are ruining everything. Straight men specifically. I like Primo in this movie but I can't bear to see that it was being played by this man.There's still some bad acting in this movie that of course, will never go in Filipino movies. And yes that was you Darren. Question, why is he here?? Seriously. Ah. I remember now. I live in the Philippines where everybody can be anything just because they can! Like just go back being a singer or do something but just please don't ever step foot in the acting industry. I think the gay best friend is doing the bare minimum too, like a little bit overacting for me because I'm a gay bestfriend too or maybe I just didn't like his character in here. I mean it's obvious to me in the start how he didn't want her to be happy and I wouldn't do that to my girl besties. It's not right for me to see Jean Garcia not acting an antagonist because she really solidified her career in those roles. Like why do I kinda need her to slap Primo in here?? The thing is, I wouldn't hate this movie so much because my friend right literally acted like George who is always coming back to her ex and I know a lot of yâ€™all are being hypocrites too because I'm sure as hell you would do the same as George or far worse. I mean that's literally one of the reasons why we don't have proper birth control in our country, right? But I'm glad the quote of â€œLove is not enoughâ€ is being taken seriously now and being the base or references of every couple now because it's always been the right statement for every couple. The ending was a lackluster for me. I mean I literally have to go through their makeup which is too long for me. It is too long just to end it with George seeing Primoâ€™s letter that he hid in the music record which is I still think why'd he have to hide in there. I don't think the finding father plot was out of place but if the results are like that then the whole Amsterdam scene should've been the time where the finally made up and spent each other's lives again together and better. In short, the yearning was too good just to have unsatisfying results. I might say that this was a good choice of movie. This is definitely Kathryn's one of best roles and I hope she continues to improve and I will continue to support her career and wish the downfall of that man on the other hand. I hope she's happy and is eating a good meal everyday. Daniel Padilla, you will burn in hell. I will make sure of that.B Tier2018 Ranked

Itâ€™s the first time Iâ€™m writing a review for a romance movie, although I do actually watch some. This one hits different when it comes to love. The way they portrayed the characters, itâ€™s just bitter yet sweet. My favorite scene is when they were outside during the rainâ€”Joyâ€™s dialogue is what youâ€™d feel the most. She was giving her pieces one by one to her love, so she was left with nothing in the end. Despite that, Primo actually received nothing, because people do not get the ability to receive that. Only to suck it up. Both of them were drained and sad and lost.For Primoâ€™s side, he was really a good man. Although for the scenes that he was facing bad things, he didnâ€™t deserve Joy nor anything from her. I pitied him. But it doesnâ€™t mean that Joy should feel that, too. Thatâ€™s why when they got away from each other, it was probably to find themselves. Thatâ€™s how I liked The Hows of Us. The ending is up to you, actually. Whether they ended up together or just friends. The only thing I hope is for them to be happy.

super, super, super gago ni primo (and i really did hate how this film tried to justify yung pagiging pabuhat niya sa buhay ni jo) but unfortunately, i can't wholeheartedly say that i disliked this.it was very quirky and fun naman in its concept! even though kathryn literally carried the whole thing by her back, i found it charming and could see why this appealed to the local masses. i love how jo's character was fleshed out and portrayed, and i loved every moment that she stood for her own ground. primo, on the other hand... well, i just don't see why people like him and why the ending with him had to be that. sure, he redeemed himself but it's like. i found it so stupid and manipulative personally (literal na throughout the whole movie i felt like pinaglalaruan lang ako ng ulol) which is why !!! a star is deducted. but if we disregard all that, then maybe this film did have an impact on me... loved the delivery of the exposition, lalo na yung direct parallels from when they were still together to 2 years after the breakup. very similar in style sa starting over again, which is fave ko. what i really loved about this movie aside from the characters is the pacing, manner of narration, and the way it portrayed how jo lost her resolve and resistance against primo, kasi relatable pa rin kahit na nakakainis at nakakairita na yung katangahan ni george. matalino naman talaga siya pero i think ang problema sa kanya is masyado niyang sineryoso ang feelings na nagresurface noong bumalik si primo, in short, masyadong marupok! remember, hindi lahat ng emotion na nararamdaman natin sa katawan ay reliable. we should never make decisions based on our feelings alone, dapat may balance between objective fact/reality and what we feel. totoo na mahal pa rin ni george si primo, pero at the same time, malaki ang kasalanan at trauma na nacause ni primo kay george, kaya hindi dapat nagpadala si george sa feelings niya at bumalik kay primo. what they need from each other is sincere apology with accountability and closure, hindi comeback. hindi deserve ni george na magstay sa taong katulad ni primo. george deserves so much better, and not the "better" that primo has to offer.

: jo, anu, ayaw m na? paghud k n4, ayaw mo na?: oo!!! pagud n pagod n4 pagod na pagud nah aku (gumiling ala-dorpina)...â€œas years passed, everything that made me fall in love with him, turned out to be the same things I hated about him.â€itâ€™s scary how we can be ugly to someone who used to see stars in our eyes..

This one hurt differentlyâ€” not in the loud, heart-wrenching way some love stories do, but in that slow ache of staying too long. Of loving past the expiration date. Of fighting for something that no longer knows how to fight back.George and Primo werenâ€™t star-crossed or tragic in the classic sense. They were real. Exhausted. Stubborn. Still soft for each other beneath the bruises of all those unfinished conversations. And maybe thatâ€™s what made it worseâ€” their love didnâ€™t end with anger. It ended with the weight of trying. Again and again. And again.I didnâ€™t cry at the big scenes.I cried when she stared at him from across the room and didnâ€™t know what to say.I cried at the way he said â€œpangarapâ€ like it used to mean us, and now it only means me.The film didnâ€™t scream. It simmered. It dragged me through the quiet cruelties of outgrowing someone you still care for. It reminded me of the version of myself I stayed with too long. The promises we tried to keep when our hearts had already started packing.And yetâ€” somehowâ€” it wasnâ€™t hopeless. It was sad, but not bitter. Thatâ€™s harder to write. Thatâ€™s harder to feel.It whispered,â€œYou loved. You outgrew. You survived.â€And sometimes, thatâ€™s the most devastating line of all.This film felt like a letter you never sent. The kind that sits in your notes app. Half bitter. Half soft. Fully human.If youâ€™ve ever loved someone deeply and had to choose yourself anywayâ€” this one will sting. Gently.

"The Hows of Usâ€ isnâ€™t your usual dreamy, rom-com na may happy-ever-after agad. It digs deeperâ€”sobrang sakit, sobrang real. This movie shows na kahit gaano kalalim ang pagmamahalan n'yo, minsan, hindi â€˜yon sapat para manatili. George and Primoâ€™s story hits hard kasi hindi ito tungkol sa how they met, kundi sa how they survived... or didnâ€™t.Pero ang ganda ng mga songs dito ha, damang-dama.Itâ€™s about love that starts with so much fire but slowly fades into frustration, broken dreams, and too many â€œsorrys.â€ Yung mga â€œI love youâ€ na eventually napalitan ng â€œPagod na ako.â€ Yung tipong mahal mo pa, pero pagod ka na. At â€˜di ba, thatâ€™s one of the worst kinds of heartbreak?Kathryn nailed it with her raw, painful deliveryâ€”lalo na sa scene kung saan sinasabi niya kung gaano siya naghihintay na lumaban si Primo."How did you not found a reason stay?""And what makes your sorry different from all your sorry before?"Ang ganda rin ng message ng film: Love isnâ€™t always magical. Minsan, love is staying, choosing, and fixingâ€”kahit ang hirap-hirap na.Tho nawala lang yung gana ko kasi bakit ganon na lang uli naging soft si George kay Primo? 7 years siyang nawala and parang tinanggap niya lang uli as if 1 week silang nag-away? Hindi man lang pinahirapan yang si Primo kahit na gusto niya pa, sinubukan niya man lang sana na i-challenge para mas masukat kung totoo na ba talaga yung pinapakita niya. Pero okay bumawi naman siya sa pagtulong kay Yohan.

this movie had a lot of potential to resonate even more however it stays as potential.it started off so strong until it expands through unnecessary stuff when the messages and themes could easily be done in a more cohesive way. it strayed off from being grounded to the typical romcom filo film which robbed it from its potential to be even more hard-hitting.Kathryn was a definite highlight, portraying the convoluted yet true experience of exhaustion and frustration but somehow, still having feelings of love.the overall message of the movie is definitely something you donâ€™t take at face value. it requires an understanding of the different complex parts of ourselves and our emotions that play into a relationship working out or not.

I don't know why, but I find comfort in this movie especially sa rising action and climax part. However, hanggang doon lang talaga ako sa movie. The first time I watched it, inis na inis ako sa ending. Kasi para bang sinasabi na, after all of the disrespect and suffering, babalik ka pa rin talaga kasi mahal mo. Okay lang if there was yearning and reminiscing, pero hanggang doon na lang sana. And to think na nangyayari 'to sa other women irl makes me irk. I don't know what's up with Star Cinema and their liking sa mga ganitong genre pero they really need to stop.

both sides were valid for me â€¦. lahat tayo ay napapagod pero we are either made from it or broken from it. si george ang isang halimbawa ng mga taong ieendure talaga ang lahat-lahat para sa pag-ibig. it was supposedly her desirable trait until she was broken from it bit by bit. sa sobrang pag-uuna niya sa mga taong mahal niya, nakalimutan niyang magtira para sa sarili niya ğŸ¥¹ inuna niya ang pag-ibig kaysa sa pangaraphabang si primo naman â€¦ inuna ang pangarap bago ang pag-ibig, at ayon ang ikinasira niya. it does hurt when your passion is not appreciated enough, at alam niyang nahihirapan din si george sakanya. it never meant he loved george less, he was just passion-driven, and that is never wrong. ang mali lang niya ay nagkulang siya para ipakita yon kay georgeeither way â€” love will either blind or wake us from reality. we do things out of spite for love even in the least expected times that we will. ibubuhos ang buong kaluluwa at pagkatao para sa taong mahal natin â€” but too much of something never ends well.

â€œin order to win a war, you have to stay together.â€that line hit hard because love isnâ€™t about avoiding conflict, itâ€™s about choosing to stay even when itâ€™s hard. the hows of us reminded me that real love isnâ€™t always romantic or dreamy. itâ€™s work, patience, and showing up even when it hurts.what stood out to me was kung gano kadali sumuko when things get painful, and how rare it is to hold on. but sometimes, like the film said, all we need is a little patience.some relationships need space to grow. others grow best together. and figuring that out is part of the journey.i learned that love means constantly choosing each other. not just when itâ€™s easy, but especially when itâ€™s not. facing the problem together, talking, being tired together, resting when needed. thatâ€™s what makes love last.i hope one day i find a kind of love that feels safe, honest, and patient. and i hope that kind of love finds me, too.

Not a single movie in my life has ever made me cry so much. legit. it's such a real story. yes, it may have covered cliched topics on relationship (aka falling for your exes blah blah blah), pero ang simple talaga ng ideya, and yet it manifests the struggles people face within a relationship, and it holds so many lessons to learn from. i also love how they promoted the house to the tita. how everything from that house has memories, how the house has their history. the tape on the floors and walls, the divided kitched and fridge, the couch. the couch where they built their dreams and hopes for the future. so much sentiment in everything they once had, and they gave it all away. but the war is over. the battle has been won. This film was okay. Cathy's movies just really have a track record for being cheater and manipulator apologists. Darren's character is one of the flaws. Not sure if it was his execution or bad writing but his 17 yo character acts like a 9 yo on some occasions, which I find weird. George's friends are lowkey annoying too. The plot was all over the place- lots of things don't make sense (eg. tita lola entrusting Primo to the house, the Amsterdam storyline, etc.)The acting, however, was very powerful here. The House of Us is a quiet kind of heartbreak. It tells the story of two people who once shared the same dreams but slowly drifted apart. It is not the loud kind of love. It is the kind that stays even when things get hard. The kind that gets tired but never fully disappears.It shows how love can be full of promises, but life can still find a way to test every one of them. They love each other deeply, but they are no longer the same people who started the journey. And that is what hurts the most. Watching two people hold on while slowly breaking inside.The film reminds you of the love you once believed would last forever. The kind that felt like home. And when that love starts to fall apart, it does not shatter all at once. It fades. Quietly. Painfully. And yet, in all the breaking, there is still hope. Hope that love, when chosen again, can still heal. Even if nothing is the same anymore.

The Hows of Us felt to me like a simple, yet not shallow romantic melodrama. It sits somewhere between emotional depth and surface-level storytelling, focusing on a couple navigating love, breakup, and reconciliation.The screenplay was simple but had an almost episodic feel to it, i wasn't annoyed by it though and actually enjoyed some of the sequences as well.The humor was a mix of slightly cringeworthy moments and genuinely funny ones.The romance, both in its joyful and sorrowful moments had a mixture of both melodramatic, over the top yet funny moments, dialogues that felt like lied between borderline cringe and genuinely touching and effectively playful at times as well The chemistry between the leads stood out. I liked them as a couple, and both gave good performances, the lady, maybe, more than the male lead, since the writers did give her a bit more importance with backstory, depth and dialogues and so the actress had more to work with in here.The Amsterdam scene was the only one that felt a little unnecessary. Even though it added depth to both characters, especially George and featured the important flower field moments, and the detailing regarding her wish to watch tulips and all, there was still something about it that felt out of place. And yeah, i guess, it was the location change that might've made me think that way.

This movie isn't just a "movie" it's an emotional rollercoaster. The film portrays the struggles of a long-term relationship facing an unexpected Crisis, moment of heartbreak,the unspoken tension, and the agonizing process of trying to rebuild the trust this movie makes you feel everything is real. It shows that being in a relationship is not all about "love", "spark", and "kilig" There are times that you'll have a fight and you'll just throw hurtful words at each other. Not all the time it's all about love, but it's all about sacrifices and devotion . You'll sacrifice everything for your loved ones, until you get drained,tired, and until you don't have anything to yourself anymore because you give them all. "The Hows of us" hit me hard when the raining scene started. I found myself completely absorbed in the character's struggles.

"I needed for you to fight for us that night because I was so tired fighting alone"Napa what if nalang talaga ako sa part na what if George read the letter in the vinyl record on her birthday? Would it change the trajectory of their story? Would it be enough to convince her to continue fighting even though she's drained and exhausted of everything? Would they still be together? And if she did, would it be worth it? ğŸ¥¹But I also realized that it's good narin na hindi niya nabasa kasi after ending things with Primo, she had a better life. Kahit mahirap at masakit para sa kanya. This made me realize that sometimes you have to lose what you thought you needed in order to make space for what you truly deserve.Maraming pagkakamali si Primo, and of course may mali din si George. Lalo na sa part na she has all the reason to walk away and leave Primo before, but she just can't kasi sobrang mahal niya. It's not her fault for loving someone at their worst. Pero sana hindi niya kinalimutan yung self worth niya. Nakakahinayang lang talaga yung years na nasayang niya taking care of Primo only to end up sacrificing her opportunity to become a doctor ğŸ¥¹This reminded me that you can love someone with all your heart but do not forget your own worth in the process. You don't have to shrink your worth just to fit someone else's comfort or expectation. Girl, you do you! âœŠAng pinaka takeaway ko sa movie na 'to is to choose wisely between love and life's priorities. Know when to stop and walk away kasi walking away is not just about giving up on love, but choosing to honor your worth and the future you've worked so hard for. Also, hindi ibigsabihin na may natapos ay tapos na. The end is just the beginning of something better. ğŸ˜‰To my girlies, I hope we won't experience what George had gone through. I hope we don't meet the Primo in our life that will make us choose between love or career. I hope we get the love that we truly deserve. ğŸ¥¹ğŸ™

you can never go wrong with Kathryn's talent for acting. it's like she really made for this. i watch this movie often just to see if my perspective will change everytime i watch this. and yeah, it changes everytime. when i first watched it in the cinema. i liked it so much that i didn't even bother to understand the real situation. i romanticized it too much just because i am a kathniel fan than time.but as time goes by, specifically now, i'm slowly getting it. Primo was so fucked up. i hate him, tbh. but i know that people like him exists (u know i love real life situation movies). that no matter how hard you try, no matter how heavy the guilt is, there is just something that limits you from going forward in life. Primo needed that time and a big slap of reality just to get him to do something with his life. i hate him but i know that if i were him, i will understand why he's like that. and to George, i understand her coming back. actually, it's okay. life is just like that. not just because we witnessed their situation, we also know what they are feeling. so i get her. all her sacrifices, i get it. some people just do that just for love. i know that not all people will understand that situation nor will do the same. but for me, i get her.

Reflection on The House of Us (2018)The 2018 Filipino film The House of Us, is an emotionally stirring drama that explores love, dreams, and the struggle to hold onto relationships despite lifeâ€™s hardships. The movie follows the story of Primo (Daniel Padilla) and George (Kathryn Bernardo), a couple whose relationship is tested by ambition, miscommunication, and the harsh realities of life. Watching this film was a deeply emotional experience, as it delved into themes that felt incredibly real and relatable. It made me reflect on the complexities of love and the sacrifices that people make to sustain their relationships.One of the most striking aspects of The House of Us is how it captures the essence of Filipino relationships and family dynamics. The plot feels deeply Filipino because of its emphasis on love as not just an emotion but also a responsibility. Many Filipinos will see themselves in George and Primo characters who represent different perspectives on dreams and commitment. The film also highlights the idea of bahay, or home, as not just a physical structure but a place built through shared experiences and struggles. This theme resonates strongly with Filipino audiences, as family and home play a crucial role in Filipino culture. The sacrifices made by George and her struggle to balance love with self-respect mirror the reality of many Filipinos who navigate relationships while trying to improve their circumstances.The film also appears to reference other works in the romance and drama genre, particularly in how it presents its narrative and themes. For instance, it shares similarities with One More Chance (2007), another Filipino film that explores second chances in love and the consequences of choices in a relationship. Like One More Chance, The House of Us portrays raw emotions and the difficult path toward forgiveness and reconciliation. Additionally, it takes inspiration from classic romance tropes found in both literature and film, such as the idea of lovers growing apart due to personal ambitions but later finding a way to reconnect. These references are used effectively to enhance the filmâ€™s storytelling, making it feel familiar yet fresh.

The Hows of Us is a truly amazing and heartwarming movie. Even though I've never been in a relationship, the film's message deeply resonated with me. It's one of the best romantic movies I've ever seen, offering a bittersweet but realistic portrayal of love. It shows how tiring relationships can get, making you want to give up, but emphasizes the importance of patience, space, and understanding your partner's feelings. The movie highlights that while separation or space can be helpful, ultimately, working together to overcome challenges and build a future is key.

"The Hows of Us" is a Philippine romantic drama that left me with a combination of emotions â€“ from the euphoria of first love to the heartache of its inevitable problems and the heartwarming process of reunion. The movie explores the intricacies of relationships, emphasizing the fluctuations that come with loving, pursuing ambitions, and developing as a person. What really makes "The Hows of Us" work is its strong Filipino identity. The movie features recognizable social dynamics, family values, and the emphasis on relationships in Filipino culture. The location, a warm and inviting home that George inherited from his late grandmother, is symbolic of the strong sense of family and tradition found in Filipino society. The struggle of the characters with family expectations, financial burdens, and the chase for their dreams is very relatable to most Filipinos.The movie's own Filipino touch can be seen in its characters, dialogue, and storyline. The characters themselves sound and look distinctly Filipino, as their body language, reactions, and dialogue all resonate well with the local population. The fact that the plot dwells so much on family, tradition, and dealing with the demands of society lends the movie a characteristically Filipino tone. "The Hows of Us" is a movie that resonates with Filipino experiences, capturing the spirit of love, family, and self-discovery in a cultural setting that is both familiar and endearing.

"The Hows of Us" is a Philippine romantic drama that left me with a combination of emotions â€“ from the euphoria of first love to the heartache of its inevitable problems and the heartwarming process of reunion. The movie explores the intricacies of relationships, emphasizing the fluctuations that come with loving, pursuing ambitions, and developing as a person. What really makes "The Hows of Us" work is its strong Filipino identity. The movie features recognizable social dynamics, family values, and the emphasis on relationships in Filipino culture. The location, a warm and inviting home that George inherited from his late grandmother, is symbolic of the strong sense of family and tradition found in Filipino society. The struggle of the characters with family expectations, financial burdens, and the chase for their dreams is very relatable to most Filipinos.The movie's own Filipino touch can be seen in its characters, dialogue, and storyline. The characters themselves sound and look distinctly Filipino, as their body language, reactions, and dialogue all resonate well with the local population. The fact that the plot dwells so much on family, tradition, and dealing with the demands of society lends the movie a characteristically Filipino tone. "The Hows of Us" is a movie that resonates with Filipino experiences, capturing the spirit of love, family, and self-discovery in a cultural setting that is both familiar and endearing.

What makes The Hows of Us distinctly Filipino is its reflection of Filipino values and culture. The film portrays the importance of family, sacrifice, and resilience â€” traits deeply embedded in Filipino society. The characters' constant balancing act between personal ambition and family responsibilities mirrors the lives of many Filipinos who prioritize loved ones over personal desires. The use of Taglish and the depiction of everyday life in the Philippines further ground the narrative in the local context. The story also touches on the "tiis-ganda" or "tiis-hirap" mindset, where characters endure hardships in the hope of a better future, a common theme in Filipino storytelling.Beyond the romance, the film resonates because it speaks to the struggles of young people chasing dreams while navigating love and financial difficulties. The heartfelt dialogue, picturesque cinematography, and moving soundtrack all contribute to its emotional appeal. The Hows of Us not only captures the highs and lows of relationships but also serves as a reflection of the resilience and hope that define the Filipino spirit.

The Hows of Us (2018) is a Filipino romantic drama film directed by Cathy Garcia-Molina and starring Kathryn Bernardo and Daniel Padilla. The film tells the story of Primo and George, a young couple who dream of a future together but struggle with the realities of love, ambition, and personal growth. Plot SummaryGeorge and Primo are college sweethearts who move in together, hoping to build a life around their shared dreams. However, their relationship is tested as Primo's pursuit of a music career leads to disappointments, while George, who is more practical, begins to question their future. The movie explores how love can be both a source of strength and a challenge when personal ambitions collide with relationships. Review As a student, the film resonates deeply because it highlights themes of ambition, sacrifice, and personal growthâ€”issues many young people face. The story is realistic, showing that love alone is not always enough to sustain a relationship. Kathryn Bernardo delivers a heartfelt performance as George, portraying the struggles of someone torn between love and self-respect. Daniel Padilla, as Primo, effectively shows the frustration of chasing dreams while holding onto a relationship. The cinematography and soundtrack add to the emotional impact, making key scenes more powerful. The script is well-written, with dialogues that capture real-life struggles. One of the most relatable aspects of the film is the message about knowing when to hold on and when to let goâ€”a lesson relevant not only in relationships but also in personal aspirations. Conclusion Overall, â€œThe Hows of Usâ€ is a must-watch, especially for students who are navigating love, career goals, and personal growth. It teaches the importance of communication, compromise, and self-worth. The movie is emotional, thought-provoking, and inspiring, making it a great film for young audiences.

"The Hows of Us" is a cinematic experience that masterfully navigates viewers through a whirlwind of emotions, making it a truly impactful film. The movie's ability to rapidly shift emotions is a testament to its storytelling effectiveness, as it delves into the intricate complexities of relationships and the profound emotional struggles of its characters. The Hows of Us* (2018) is an affecting study in love, sacrifice, and the trials of maturing togetherâ€”or apartâ€”through time. Directed by Cathy Garcia-Molina and starring Kathryn Bernardo and Daniel Padilla, the film tracks Primo and George, a couple whose erstwhile brilliant future is gradually extinguished by ambition, disillusionment, and the harsh realities of adulthood.What is particularly Filipino about *The Hows of Us* is its visceral emotional center, one that speaks to the very notion of *hugot*â€”that bare, gut-level pull of emotion oftentimes associated with individual histories of love and heartbreak. Primo's quest for his ambitions, with George lugging the burden of prudence, reflects a common Filipino dynamic in which aspiration and responsibility tend to war against one another. The fact that *pamilya* is an important consideration in their choices also makes the story more rooted in Filipino culture, reaffirming the way that love is seldom just between two individuals, but wrapped up in family obligations. The movie also toys with the concept of *sayang*â€”that aching, lingering sorrow when love fails because of everything. Although *The Hows of Us* provides closure, it dwells on the heartache of nearly losing someone, so it is understandable to anyone who has ever clung to love a little too long. It does not merely pose the question of whether love is worth fighting for, but whether love by itself is ever sufficient.Would the life of Primo and George have been the same if they were not in the Philippines? Maybe not. The cultural significance of *kapit* (holding on), *tiis* (patience), and the anticipation of *pagtatagal* (enduring love) influence their journey. Deep down, *The Hows of Us* is not simply a love storyâ€”it is a testament to what it is to love as a Filipino.

The Hows of Us is a beautifully written film that captures the complexities of love, commitment, and personal growth in a long-term relationship. The screenplay is deeply emotional and relatable, presenting a realistic portrayal of how love isn't just about grand romantic gestures but also about patience, sacrifice, and navigating life's uncertainties together.As filipino Madami sa atin ang gaya ni George. Na sinasabi natin na pagod na tayo, na umalis na sila sa buhay natin. Pero deep inside, ang gusto natin ay habulin tayo at higit sa lahat ay wag tayo iwan kahit anong pag papaalis natin sakanila. Dahil nga pagod lang tayo at kailangan lang ng konting pahinga. What makes the film so well-written is its ability to balance raw emotions with meaningful dialogue, showing how relationships evolve over time. Ithighlights the struggles of chasing dreams while maintaining a relationship, the resentment that can build when one person feels left behind, and the challenge of deciding whether love is enough to keep two people together.

The Hows of Us feels distinctly "Filipino" to me, especially in how Kath, despite being busy with her studies and preparing for an important examâ€”on top of dealing with the stress brought by Danielâ€”still chose to care for him, even at the cost of her own well-being. It reflects the selflessness we often show for our loved ones. As Filipinos, we tend to compromise on things that matter to us, but when it comes to the people we love, we willingly make sacrifices.

I have already watched this movie multiple times, from cinema to netflix, yet it does not change the excitement and kilig I feel everytime I watch it. The kilig when Primo & George's relationship was just starting, the happiness I felt with them when their relationship worked for years, and also the anger when things started to go downhill and Primo chose to be selfish, self-centered, immature and impractical with the decisions he made which greatly affected George's mental health and career because she put Primo on top of her priority, especially over her exam. Truly, love can make people do crazy things, not thinking and considering the consequences that comes with it. The movie also portrayed the importance of maintaining the teamwork in the relationship, the "doing things together" even with the smallest thing. Most importantly, the show is an eye opener of the beauty of growing, even if it means the need of growing apart. The beauty of exploring life outside your comfort zone, facing your fears and conquering what the world has for you outside your shell. After all, if things are really meant to happen, no matter how many turns, delays or challenges you both face in life, fate will have its own way of bringing you back to each other's life. At that time, you both are grown up, able to make decisions that also considers your partner and has a different perspectives in life, making you love each other in the right wayâ€”the way you both deserve to love and to be loved. Just like how fate brought back Primo and George together after years of not having communication, both shared different life realizations and lessons that made them who they were when they met again. One thing just did not change after years of being apart, the fact that they will always be the missing part of each other, the one that will complete the empty and dull space of their lives.

"The Hows of Us" is a poignant exploration of love, sacrifice, and the complexities of sustaining a long-term relationship. Unlike many conventional romance films that often present fairy-tale endings and idealized narratives, this movie authentically examines the tough choices couples must face, especially the delicate balance between pursuing personal dreams and nurturing a commitment to a loved one.The palpable chemistry between Kathryn Bernardo and Daniel Padilla enhances the emotional depth of their charactersâ€™ journey. The film expertly integrates "hugot" linesâ€”expressions that resonate with real-life experiences of heartbreak and hopeâ€”adding a layer of relatability that connects with viewers on a personal level.A defining aspect of this film is its depiction of Filipino values, particularly the emphasis on perseverance, the significance of family, and the necessity of shared responsibilities. These principles are fundamental to Filipino relationships, allowing George and Primoâ€™s struggles to resonate even more profoundly with the audience. Their story intertwines themes of survival and mutual support, grounding their experience in a relatable reality.Moreover, "The Hows of Us" leaves a lasting impression by conveying that love encompasses far more than grand gestures or passionate romances. It illustrates that true love often requires hard work, compromise, and a steadfast commitment to one anotherâ€”especially during challenging times. The film ultimately serves as a poignant reminder that enduring love is forged not only through moments of joy but also amid shared struggles and unwavering dedication to each other.

"The Hows of Us" pinatunayan sa atin na walang patutunguhan ang isang relasyon kung may isa sa inyo ang makasarili. Primo is egotistical, too ambitious, and self-centered. I understand; he wants to provide for their future and be successful, but in the end, he loses. He had forgotten the concept of relationship. He was so focused on his ambition that he forgot he had a partner who needed him.Conversely, George shows that when a woman falls in love, she is prepared to jeopardize everything to validate her worthiness.Every relationship has its own unique set of stories, problems, and dreams. However, we all know that we all desire the same ending: "Happily ever after". LOVE is more than just passion or practicality; it is about mutual respect, understanding, and compromise. Primo becomes more open and supportive of George's artistic ambitions, seeing that her dreams are an integral part of who she is. He learns to be more open about his personal needs and worries, rather than focusing solely on providing for their future.George, in turn, learns to understand that partnerships involve effort, and that love is more than just beautiful gestures; it is also about overcoming obstacles together. She understands that they may still dream together, but they must learn to compromise and talk openly. In the film's last minutes, they are seen heading forward together, hand in hand, with a fresh sense of dedication to one other. While their relationship may never be perfect, they have matured and learnt to negotiate their differences in a healthier manner, indicating a bright future. The film, demonstrating that love necessitates ongoing effort, understanding, and adaptationâ€”all of which Primo and George are now prepared to accept.

"The Hows of Us" is a beautifully written film that takes viewers on an emotional rollercoaster. I appreciate how realistically it portrays a love that isn't always perfect; it shows a relationship enduring difficulties.The film's Filipino essence is embodied in George's unwavering support for Primo. She silently bears the weight of their struggles, believing in his potential for success. Despite her exhaustion, she remains supportive, only voicing her burden when she can no longer endure it. Her immense sacrifice exemplifies the Filipino concept of "tanga sa pag-ibig", yet her actions are entirely understandable, stemming from her deep love and faith in Primo.I loved how each character's growth leads to self-discovery, particularly Primo's understanding of sacrifice and his ability to overcome his pride.Primo and George's journey isn't perfect; it demands significant sacrifices and overcoming numerous challenges. Nonetheless, the film emphasizes the importance of individual and couple growth. It teaches us that relationships don't stifle dreams; rather, shared dreams foster growth. Choosing to love someone means accepting them despite life's hardships.

"The Hows of Us" is such an amazing and inspiring movie that I would recommend to everyone. Reflection on The Hows of UsThe Hows of Us is a deeply emotional film that resonated with me on many levels. It made me feel a mix of sadness, hope, and pride, as it told a story of love and perseverance that felt both universal and uniquely Filipino. The struggles of George and Primo, balancing love with personal growth and ambition, struck a chord because they reflect real-life challenges many young couples face, especially in the Philippines.What makes the movie distinctly Filipino is its emphasis on family, sacrifice, and resilience. Georgeâ€™s deep sense of responsibility, not just for herself but for her shared dreams with Primo, mirrors the Filipino value of bayanihan or communal support. The setting, with its familiar homes, vibrant streets, and local culture, immediately evokes the everyday life of many Filipinos. Even the charactersâ€™ names, George and Primo, feel relatable and authentic, reflecting how Filipino names often carry simplicity and charm.The way the characters look and speak also feels Filipino. Kathryn Bernardo and Daniel Padilla embody a natural, down-to-earth aesthetic that resonates with Filipino audiences. Their dialogue, filled with a mix of English and Filipino (Taglish), reflects how many Filipinos communicate. The humor, the dramatic expressions, and even the moments of silence between them capture the essence of how Filipinos connect and express themselves in relationships.The plot itself feels inherently Filipino because it revolves around themes of sacrifice, enduring hardship, and chasing dreams despite adversity. Primoâ€™s struggle to pursue his passion for music, even as it strains his relationship with George, reflects the Filipino spirit of pangarap (dreaming big) and the tension it creates within relationships and families. Georgeâ€™s ultimate decision to prioritize herself is a powerful message about self-love, but it is also rooted in the idea that love requires strength and compromiseâ€”values deeply embedded in Filipino culture.This story couldnâ€™t have unfolded the same way if the characters werenâ€™t Filipino. The cultural backdrop, their ways of handling conflict, and their resilience are shaped by the Filipino way of life. The charactersâ€™ dreams, their struggles with finances, and their deep connections to family and tradition are experiences many Filipinos can relate to.The film also nods to other works in Filipino cinema, especially the tradition of romantic dramas that deal with heartbreak and redemption. Its themes are universal, yet the Filipino flavor in its storytelling, dialogue, and values make it stand out. On the other hand, The Hows of Us has become iconic in itself, often referenced in memes and conversations about modern relationships in the Philippines. Lines like â€œIâ€™m so tiredâ€ have become symbolic of emotional struggles, and the movie has been hailed as a modern classic in Filipino romance films.In conclusion, The Hows of Us is more than a love story; itâ€™s a reflection of Filipino culture and values. It speaks to the heart of what it means to love, to dream, and to growâ€”both as individuals and as a coupleâ€”while staying true to oneâ€™s roots. Itâ€™s a film that Filipinos can see themselves in, and thatâ€™s what makes it so impactful.

Watching The Hows of Us felt like going through a rollercoaster of emotionsâ€”one moment, you're swooning over Primo and Georgeâ€™s sweet moments, and the next, youâ€™re feeling the weight of their struggles. This film is more than just a love story; itâ€™s a reflection of real-life relationships, the sacrifices people make for love, and the painful reality that sometimes, love alone isnâ€™t enough. :)One of the most striking things about The Hows of Us is how undeniably Filipino it feels. The story revolves around dreams, sacrifices, and the struggle between love and personal ambitionâ€”things that many Filipinos, especially the younger generation, can deeply relate to. George and Primoâ€™s relationship isnâ€™t the sugarcoated romance we often see in mainstream rom-coms. Itâ€™s raw, messy, and full of the kind of emotional punches that make you reflect on your own relationships, whether theyâ€™re romantic, familial, or even personal aspirations that require difficult choices.The film also captures a very Filipino dynamicâ€”the expectation to endure, to stay, to fight for love even when things get unbearably hard. It highlights the cultural sentiment of â€œsayangâ€ when relationships donâ€™t work out, as if every failed relationship is a lost investment rather than a lesson. The setting, the way the characters talk, the family pressures, and even the concept of diskarte in life and love all feel so close to home.As for hugot, The Hows of Us is full of it. "The Hows of Us," a KathNiel starrer, isn't just another romantic comedy; it's a poignant exploration of love, commitment, and the messy realities of long-term relationships. Primo and George, the film's central characters, navigate the highs and lows of their shared dreams, facing challenges that range from career setbacks to family disapproval. The movie cleverly interweaves their present struggles with flashbacks of their blossoming romance, offering a compelling look at how time and circumstance can impact even the strongest bonds. While the film certainly delivers the kilig moments KathNiel fans expect, it also delves into deeper emotional territory, prompting viewers to reflect on their own relationships and the sacrifices love often demands.Personally, "The Hows of Us" resonated with me because it portrayed a relationship that felt real and relatable. It wasn't a fairytale romance; it was a story about two people trying to make it work, even when things got tough. I appreciated the film's honesty in depicting the arguments, the insecurities, and the moments of doubt that are inevitable in any long-term partnership. It reminded me that love isn't always sunshine and rainbows; it's also about navigating storms together and choosing to stay, even when it's hard. The film's exploration of dreams, both individual and shared, also struck a chord. It highlighted the importance of supporting each other's aspirations, even when they diverge from the initial plan.On social media, I'd caption a still from the movie with something like, "Love isn't about finding someone you can live with, it's about finding someone you can't live without... even when they drive you crazy. #TheHowsOfUs #Hugot #KathNiel #RelateMuch". Another post could feature a picture of George crying with the caption, "Sometimes, love means letting go. But sometimes, it also means fighting harder. Which one is the real deal? #TheHowsOfUs #LoveLessons #KathNiel #DeepThoughts". These "hugot" lines capture the emotional core of the film and tap into the universal experiences of love, loss, and the complexities of human relationships.The film's plot twist revolves around the true meaning of the "hows" in the title. While the audience initially assumes it refers to the practicalities of a relationship (how to live together, how to manage finances, etc.), the twist reveals a deeper meaning. It turns out that the "hows" refer to the different ways people love. Primo's love language is acts of service and providing for George, while George expresses her love through words and emotional support. The film highlights how these different "hows" can sometimes clash, leading to misunderstandings and hurt feelings. The resolution comes when they finally understand and appreciate each other's unique ways of loving, realizing that love isn't just about grand gestures but also about recognizing and valuing the small, everyday expressions of affection.

Ang kwento ay nag simula ng si George at Primo na sa umpisa ay mag kamag aral na nagkaibigan. Ng mag kolehiyo si George ay tumuloy sa pag aaral ng medisina habang si primo itunuloy na isang maging sikat na musikero sa pamamagitan ng pag babanda. Sila ay nanirahan sa loob ng iisang bahay habang sabay na nangagarap ng magandang buhay at nangako sa isat isa na susuportahan at isat isa. Lumipas ang mga araw ang pangarap ni Primo na sumikat bilang isang musikero ay di nag tagumpay. Dahil dito nag iba ang kanyang pag uugali hanggang sa umabot na pati ang kanyang mga kaibigan at kabanda ay pinili na lumayo sa kanya. Habang si Primo nag bago, si George ay patuloy na iniintindi at minamahal si primo kahit ang kapalit nito ay ang kanyang pang sariling kasiyahan at pangarap . Sa kasamaang palad lahat ng bagay ay may hangganan ng si George ay napuno na sa ikinikilos at ginagawa ni Primo kaya naman kahit labag sa loob pinaalis ni Goerge si Primo sa kanilang bahay na tinutulyan. Naklipas ang ilang taon, habang si George ay tinuloy ang pag aaral ng medisina. Si primo naman ay nag bago at bumalik sa pag asang magkabalikan sila.Sa aking opinion sinisimbolo ng kanilang bahay ang kanilang estado o kalagayan. May mga bagay na gusto nilang punuin sa bahay na iyon tulad ng malaking 65 inches na TV at sofa, ngunit kalaunan ay hindi nila nagawa. Parang sa relasyon nilang dalawa, may mga bagay na gusto nilang mangyari, mga bagay na pinangarap nilang makamit ngunit hindi nangyari dahil sa sakim na katotohanan ng buhay. Aking nagustuhan sa pelikula ay ang kakayanan nitong ipakita ang hindi makasariling pag-ibig. Pinapakita dito kung paano magmahal ang pagod na puso. Ang mga pangako, panghihinayang, at paghihirap. Kung paano kayang buhusin ng isang tao ang kanyang sarili para sa pagmamahal. Kung paano ito patuloy na tumatayo, subukan man ng mga realidad ng buhay.

â€œThe Hows of Usâ€ is a Filipino movie that depicts the challenges experienced in a long-term relationship such as family dynamics, sacrifice, and resilience. It is centered around two values that all relationships in the Philippines share: tiis (endurance) and alaga (nurturing). The film also emphasizes the desire to go overseas that most in the average Filipino family has. Characters Primo and George embody the passionate, sometimes stubborn, but ultimately kindhearted Filipino dreamer, while George stands for the ate (elder sister) character. The things they say and do depict what real relationships would look like to their fellow countrymen. This is framed by the more serious undertones of what love can mean in the Philippines, which is full of tadhana (fate), enduring love, and personal sacrifice. This film is full of hugot moments, especially when George says: â€œDati gusto kitang makasama pangarapin â€˜yung mga bagay na gusto natin. Ngayon, gusto na lang kitang makasama kahit wala na â€˜yung mga pangarap natin.â€ That line hits hard because it reflects the painful realization that love sometimes requires letting go of dreams.

The Hows of Us (2018) takes a familiar romance-drama formula and injects it with a uniquely Filipino emotional weight. At its core, the film explores the struggles of long-term relationships, the sacrifices made for love, and the inevitable tension between personal dreams and shared commitments.What makes it distinctly Filipino is how it portrays tiisâ€”the kind of endurance that many Filipinos, especially in relationships, hold on to even when things seem hopeless. George (Kathryn Bernardo) and Primo (Daniel Padilla) feel like real people, with George embodying the practical, hardworking Filipina who shoulders more than she should, and Primo representing the dreamer whose ambitions often come at a cost. Their dynamic feels all too familiar, echoing real-life relationships where one partner gives more, hoping the other will eventually change.The film resonates because it doesnâ€™t just rely on hugot lines; it captures the quiet, painful moments of love falling apart. It asks a question that many Filipinos face: When is love no longer enough? And while it gives a hopeful resolution, it never diminishes the emotional toll of staying in a relationship thatâ€™s slowly breaking you.Itâ€™s a heavy watch, but itâ€™s also a necessary oneâ€”reminding us that love isnâ€™t just about how we stay, but why we choose to.

The Hows of Us feels deeply Filipino in many ways, making it easy for audiences to connect with the story.1. Family Comes First â€“ Unlike Western romances that focus just on the couple, this film highlights how family plays a big role in relationships. George takes care of her younger brother, and Primo struggles with family expectations, showing the Filipino value of utang na loob (debt of gratitude).2. Love, Sacrifice, and Destiny â€“ The movie reflects the Filipino belief in tadhana (destiny) and habambuhay na pag-ibig (lifelong love), where love is worth fighting for despite hardships. Georgeâ€™s patience with Primo and his journey to redemption mirror the sacrifices many Filipinos make for love.3. Familiar Names and Language â€“ George (Georgina) and Primo are names that feel natural in Filipino culture, and the dialogue blends English and Tagalog, just like everyday conversations in the Philippines.4. Authentic Filipino Settings â€“ From traditional homes and Manilaâ€™s busy streets to picturesque scenes in Amsterdam, the locations reflect real-life strugglesâ€”staying in the Philippines or chasing dreams abroad.5. Dreams vs. Reality â€“ Primoâ€™s passion for music and Georgeâ€™s need for stability represent a common Filipino dilemma: following your dreams or choosing practicality.6. Heartfelt Hugot â€“ The film is packed with emotional lines that hit home, like â€œPagod na ako. Kakahintay, kakasalo, kakaisip kung may patutunguhan ba tayo.â€ These deep, relatable moments make the story even more impactful.Overall, The Hows of Us isnâ€™t just a love story but itâ€™s a reflection of real Filipino relationships, values, and struggles.

â€œThe Hows of Usâ€ is about a couple who have been together for years but are starting to feel the strain of chasing their own dreams while trying to keep their love alive. Watching this movie made me feel a lot of emotionsâ€”frustration, sadness, and even a bit of hope. It felt so real, like it was showing a love story that could easily happen to anyone. The idea of sacrificing for love, even when it seems like itâ€™s not working anymore, is something deeply rooted in our culture. Filipinos often hold on to relationships, even when they get difficult, because we value family and long-term commitment so much.This movie made me reflect on love, sacrifice, and the idea that not all relationships are meant to last. Sometimes, people grow apart despite their best efforts, and thatâ€™s something everyone can relate to. Itâ€™s a bittersweet story, and it hits hard because it feels so familiar.

The film follows George and Primo, a couple who started with big dreams and promises but slowly fell apart due to unbalanced sacrifices and priorities. While the movie tries to capture the highs and lows of love, I didnâ€™t like the way it was portrayed because there could have been a better way to show the struggles of a long-term relationship. Instead of making it about real growth and compromise, it felt like George was the only one making sacrifices while Primo kept making excuses.What made this film distinctly Filipino was how deeply rooted it was in the idea of perseverance in relationships. Many Filipinos are taught to hold on, to be patient, and to fix what is broken instead of walking away. George embodied thisâ€”she kept choosing Primo even when he continuously let her down. This is a common theme in hugot films: the painful reality that love alone is not enough.Kathryn Bernardoâ€™s performance as George was incredibly raw and emotional. Her frustration and exhaustion felt so real, especially in that powerful confrontation scene. Meanwhile, Primoâ€™s character was frustrating to watchâ€”he was selfish, immature, and only realized his mistakes when it was almost too late. His actions throughout the film made it clear that George deserved better, and it was exhausting to see her continuously put up with him.One of the most heartbreaking moments in the movie was when George was on her way to take her board exam. She was already in the jeep, finally choosing herself and her future, but she still got off to check on Primo. That moment was painful to watch because it showed how much of herself she had given to himâ€”even when she was about to take one of the most important exams of her life, she still prioritized him. It was frustrating, but it also reflected the reality of many relationships where one person keeps giving while the other keeps taking.Another scene that struck me was when George confronted Primo and said, â€œKahit cupcake, hindi mo ako mabigyan.â€ That line wasnâ€™t just about a cupcakeâ€”it was about all the little efforts that Primo never made, the small but meaningful ways he could have shown he cared but never did. It summed up how unreciprocated Georgeâ€™s love and sacrifices had been, and it was heartbreaking to see her reach her breaking point.Some people say romance films feel â€œsayangâ€ when the leads donâ€™t end up together, but I donâ€™t think thatâ€™s always the case. In The Hows of Us, I honestly wouldnâ€™t have minded if George had walked away for good. The emotional damage was already there, and she had given so much of herself without getting anything in return. While the film tries to redeem Primo in the end, it doesnâ€™t erase the fact that George had to suffer before he even realized her worth. The story would have been just as powerfulâ€”if not moreâ€”if George had chosen herself instead.That being said, I also canâ€™t blame George for acting the way she did. One thing Iâ€™ve learned and seen from people around me is that love isnâ€™t universalâ€”everyone experiences it differently. Love can be complex and complicated to the point that it doesnâ€™t make sense to others anymore. Even though I think she deserved better, if she couldnâ€™t see it, then thereâ€™s no point. Itâ€™s her love, her story, and her choice.This movie made me reflect on love and sacrifice. How much should someone give before realizing theyâ€™ve lost themselves? Does love always have to come with suffering? While the film gives hope in the end, it also makes you question whether some relationships are worth holding on to or if letting go is the better choice.

Watching Primo and George fight for their love, I saw a version of myself I once hated: someone who let go, not because I wanted to, but because I thought I had to. Primoâ€™s dreams made him feel unworthy; mine were just excuses to run. Hindi ko matanggap na may taong kayang mahalin ako sa kabila ng lahat ng imperfections ko. So I left before they could change their mind.George stayed and fought. I didnâ€™t.This film isnâ€™t just about loveâ€”itâ€™s about timing, self-worth, and the ugly, painful reality that sometimes, the person who loves us the most is the one we push away. Not because we donâ€™t love them back, but because we donâ€™t know how to love ourselves enough to believe we deserve them.And the worst part? Minsan, walang second chance. This movie made me wonder, when is the greatest time to fall in love. when is the greatest time to settle and be a fool for someone. my brain is telling me na itâ€™s better pag may naipundar naâ€”may narating. my heart is telling me, mas mabuting maaga. hindi ba ang romantic pag nakasama mo sila lumaki? through ups and downs ika nga. nakakatuwa rin na anjan sila, hindi nasa pundar ng iba. okay lang siguro kung ilalaan nila para sa future sarili nila katulad mo para wala silang babalikan, pero possible na hindi. dapat bang unahan mo na yung iba? hindi ba may mga taong bumabalik talaga sa mga nakakasama nila noong nasa journey sila na katulad ni daniel? nakakatakot kung sarili ko lang mababalikan ko dahil hindi ako nag hangad. o baka naman takot lang akong mapagisa at hindi maranasan yung ganito kaya ako natatakot.after watching this movie, my question remains unanswered. but i realized that i shouldnâ€™t be afraid because there will most likely be many journeys ahead of meâ€”may pipili rin sa sayo. also, bakit ba gustong-gusto kong may angkinin, there must be a reason pero i should fix it. nonetheless, i admire how realistic this movie is.

Pinanood ko â€˜tong film na â€˜to nung kakabreak pa lang ng (now exes)KathNiel. It felt so real, overwhelming. Ang tanga lang ni Jo for giving up her dreams for a severely drunk Primo but, I would do the same if I were her. Ramdam na ramdam ko yung bawat emosyon sa lines nilang dalawa kaya napaisip ako na â€œAhâ€¦baka ganito rin sila during that time.â€ Pero, sino ba â€˜ko para magassume sa relasyon ng ibang tao? I relate both to Primo and George. One, being Primoâ€”I saw myself in him as someone who is overly-passionate about what I really love but only to become an unexpected disappointment. Two, being Georgeâ€”George was a realistic character, who stayed, tried to understand the situation despite hindering her from furthering her dreams, still stayed, almost left, left the dream for a man, and left completelyâ€”but, she still pursued, hindi pa kasi masiyadong late para magsimula ulitâ€”mahaba ang buhay, do and pursue what you really want to do. Live the most out of the remaining time, you wonâ€™t run out of opportunities.

This confused me on some personal things. As to why should we forgive and still choose the same person who hurt us. How do we forget and still love unconditionally. Looking back at it, George should've not forgiven Primo.But then I found my current partner and understood that in a relationship mistakes are never one sided, both didn't feel assured. They had different priorities but one lacked more and made it difficult to his partner. We used to fight like George and Primo. We would throw things, say things we dislike about each other; cried and despised but still gave us both plenty of chances. We took turns into staying in the living room whenever we fought and thinking about it now makes me laugh. We love each other on our best days and understand us more on our worst. I would sing him "hanggang kailan" that Primo sang to George and just like him, my bf takes care of my family like his own. This movie kind of reminds me of us.

PANGET. Don't waste your time.Ito na yun? I've read wattpad stories with better plot and script honestly. Typical Cathy Garcia writing, puro toxicity nalang at forced positivity.Ito din pala yung movie na kinailangan ni D ng break from showbiz. Jusko, akala ko naman kung anong method acting yung pinakita niya, he was just playing himself. For all i know, they had to add that rain scene kasi hindi siya makaiyak. Jusko, buhat na buhat ni Kath yung movie. "Bakit, hindi ba ako box office king?" Gets ko na yung sinasabi nila na kung wala yan siya sa KN, he wouldn't have been BOK. Tsaka bakit ang daming unnecessary characters and storyline just to make us empathize with the mc. Tapos yung revelation sa ending, wow I've never seen anything like that before. It actually took me to watch two whole movies, several skips and increasing the movie speed into 1.5x just to finish it.Naappreciate ko bigla yung acting ni Alden. At least siya kaya niyang i-match yung acting skills ni Kath. Honestly i was supposed to just give this 1Â½ stars pero nag-add ako .5 para kay Kath and kay Kath only.

This is one of the most powerful intros for a Filipino movie that I've seen. I was surprised that the highlights and confrontation scenes were shown in the first few minutes, which was a good way to keep the audience engaged throughout the whole movie. It was a nice way of storytelling, starting from the conflict and later bringing us to the future of both characters and how they will reconcile in the end.
